subject: Sexual Health
title: Long-Acting vs Short-Acting Methods
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Long-Acting vs Short-Acting Methods.

hook.text: Some methods last minutes. Others last years. Duration shapes both effectiveness and convenience.

buildup.text: Short-acting methods like pills and condoms require action each day or each encounter.

discovery.text: Long-acting reversible contraceptives like IUDs and implants work for 3 to 12 years once placed.

twist.text: LARCs have the lowest failure rates of any reversible method because they remove human error entirely.

climax.text: Health organizations worldwide now recommend LARCs as first-line options for most people seeking contraception.

punchline.text: Less to remember means fewer unplanned pregnancies.

quiz.question: Why do LARCs have the lowest failure rates?
options: They remove human error from the equation
